title.value: Trust No Bot: Discovering Personal Disclosures in Human-LLM Conversations in the Wild
title.justification: The title 'Trust No Bot: Discovering Personal Disclosures in Human-LLM Conversations in the Wild' accurately reflects the paper's focus on understanding how personal information is disclosed in conversations with large language models (LLMs) like chatbots.
title.quote: Trust No Bot: Discovering Personal Disclosures in Human-LLM Conversations in the Wild

extractions.description: The paper explores the disclosure of personal information in user interactions with large language models, specifically chatbots. It analyzes user conversations to identify sensitive information shared, including personally identifiable information (PII) and non-PII sensitive topics. The study uses the WildChat dataset and contributes taxonomies of tasks and sensitive topics to better understand the contexts of information sharing.

type.justification: The paper conducts an extensive, fine-grained analysis of real user interactions with large language models and evaluates the presence of sensitive information using datasets, indicating empirical research.
type.quote: We run an extensive, fine-grained analysis on the personal disclosures made by real users to commercial GPT models...

name.justification: The paper is focused on analyzing conversations between humans and large language models to identify personal disclosures, which is an aspect of computational linguistics.
The paper investigates privacy concerns related to the disclosure of personal information in human-LLM interactions, making it a topic of privacy research.
name.quote: Measuring personal disclosures made in human-chatbot interactions can provide a better understanding of usersâ€™ AI literacy and facilitate privacy research for large language models (LLMs).

name.justification: The paper examines user interactions with chatbots, categorizing tasks and topics that capture how sensitive information is shared, relevant to human-computer interaction.
name.quote: To understand the contexts in which users disclose to chatbots, we develop a taxonomy of tasks and sensitive topics, based on qualitative and quantitative analysis of naturally occurring conversations.

name.justification: Large Language Models are repeatedly referenced as the technology behind the chatbots being studied for personal disclosures.
name.quote: Commercial chatbots based on large language models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT are used by millions of users...

is_contributed.justification: The paper does not introduce new language models but rather analyzes user interactions with existing models like ChatGPT.
is_contributed.quote: Commercial chatbots based on large language models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT...

is_executed.justification: The models are evidently executed as they form the basis of the data analyzed in the paper.
is_executed.quote: We explore mentions of PII and sensitive topics in naturally occurring user-chatbot conversations using the WildChat dataset...

is_compared.justification: The focus is on analyzing user interactions rather than comparing the performance of the language models with each other.
is_compared.quote: We explore mentions of PII and sensitive topics in naturally occurring user-chatbot conversations...

referenced_paper_title.justification: This well-cited paper by Brown et al. (2020) is likely referred to as it discusses the capability of language models, relevant to understanding models like ChatGPT.
referenced_paper_title.quote: More concretely, our main contributions include... over a series of experiments... and novel taxonomies (Brown et al., 2020);

name.justification: WildChat is prominently mentioned as the dataset used for analyzing user interactions with GPT models.
name.quote: We explore mentions of PII and sensitive topics in naturally occurring user-chatbot conversations using the WildChat dataset (Zhao et al., 2024)...

referenced_paper_title.value: (inthe)wildchat: 570k chatGPT interaction logs in the wild
referenced_paper_title.justification: This referenced paper by Zhao et al. is likely providing the dataset used for the research.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We explore mentions of PII and sensitive topics in naturally occurring user-chatbot conversations using the WildChat dataset (Zhao et al., 2024)...

name.justification: ShareGPT is another dataset mentioned for analysis alongside WildChat, offering comparative insights.
name.quote: As a point of comparison, we also provide analysis with another dataset ShareGPT Chiang et al. (2023)...

referenced_paper_title.value: ShareGPT: Conversations with OpenAI's ChatGPT shared by users
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is cited for comparative analysis to understand user interactions with chatbots.
referenced_paper_title.quote: As a point of comparison, we also provide analysis with another dataset ShareGPT Chiang et al. (2023), which is conversations that GPT users have opted to share.

name.value: Azure AI language PII detection service
name.justification: This library is explicitly mentioned as used for the detection of personal identifiable information in the datasets.
name.quote: We measure the frequency of PII in the two datasets using existing tools and taxonomies. To perform PII detection, we use the Python SDK of the commercial Azure AI language PII detection service...

referenced_paper_title.value: Azure Cognitive Services: The LUIS Service
referenced_paper_title.justification: While not a direct citation in the research paper, Azure's branded consumer AI services represent similar technologies to those described.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We measure the frequency of PII in the two datasets using existing tools and taxonomies. To perform PII detection, we use the Python SDK of the commercial Azure AI language PII detection service...
